title: Mediation
introduction:
You can use the help of a mediator if you can’t agree on some issues. Mediators won’t take sides or give you legal advice but will show all the options available to you.

Using a mediator is quicker and less stressful than going to court.

cost.info:
The average cost of a mediation session is £80.
Most people need between 1 and 2 sessions.

You must first meet with a mediator to check if it’s right for you. This is called a Mediation Information and Assessment Meeting (MIAM).

The average cost of a MIAM is £30.

If you don’t work, or are on a low income, you may be able to get legal aid

helpline.info:
01920 443 834 (Family Mediation Council)
Calls charged at a local rate

pros.text: 4 times quicker and 5 times cheaper than going to court;
less stressful, with less conflict between you and your partner;
gives you more control – in court a judge will make the decision;
easier on your children and helps them continue important family relationships;
Mediation works for most people – two thirds of couples who attend reach an agreement.

cons.text: Agreements made in mediation aren’t legally binding although you can hire a solicitor to check your new arrangements.

Mediation shouldn’t be considered when someone’s safety is at risk, for example where domestic violence or child abuse is involved. If you have evidence of the violence or abuse you can take your case straight to court without having to consider mediation.

You may qualify for legal aid to do this
